title: 112_s464
content: The "End Abuse in Later Life Act of 2011" is also known as the Enhanced Training and Services to End Abuse in Later Life Act. This act amends the Violence Against Women Act of 1994 to provide enhanced training and services to address abuse in later life. The "End Abuse in Later Life Act of 2011" aims to provide training, consultation, and services to address abuse in later life, including domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, stalking, exploitation, and neglect. It also seeks to create a coordinated community response to such abuse. The "End Abuse in Later Life Act of 2011" defines key terms like 'later life' as individuals aged 50 or older and 'neglect' as the failure to provide necessary goods or services for health and safety. The Act authorizes grants for eligible entities to conduct training programs to address abuse in later life. The "End Abuse in Later Life Act of 2011" authorizes grants for training programs to assist law enforcement, prosecutors, agencies, and courts in recognizing and addressing abuse in later life, including domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, stalking, exploitation, and neglect. It also aims to provide or enhance services for victims of abuse in later life. The "End Abuse in Later Life Act of 2011" authorizes grants for training programs to assist in recognizing and addressing abuse in later life, including domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, stalking, exploitation, and neglect. It aims to establish collaborative community responses and conduct cross-training for various agencies and organizations to better serve victims of abuse in later life. Eligible entities include local governments, Indian Tribal governments, population-specific organizations, victim service providers, and domestic violence or sexual assault coalitions. The entities must be part of a multidisciplinary partnership. The "End Abuse in Later Life Act of 2011" authorizes grants for training programs and outreach activities to support victims of abuse in later life. Priority is given to proposals providing population-specific services to underserved populations. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2012 to 2016. Amounts appropriated for fiscal years 2012 through 2016 shall remain available until expended and may only be used for specified activities. The Attorney General may allocate funds for administrative costs and evaluation purposes. The Attorney General may allocate up to 5 percent of funds for program evaluation contracts. Research on abuse in later life is conducted with $3,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year 2012 through 2016. The Violence Against Women Act of 1994 is amended to include a definition of "abuse in later life" as any action against a person aged 50 or older that results in physical harm, mental anguish, or deprivation of goods or services with harmful intent.
